title: Moments when friend groups become awkward when there is a lot of talk
description: The conversation continues, but when you get home, you feel strangely tired. We've outlined what misunderstandings arise from which combinations and even the solution routines that can be used right away.

sections.title: TOP 3 compatibility patterns that often appear in friend groups

items.title: 1) When ‘jokes/facts’ sound in different languages
items.when: I said this as a joke, but one person took it seriously and the mood dropped.
items.why: If there are different interpretations of ‘what comes first right now’ – jokes, facts, or emotions – the same statement can sound like an attack.
items.tip: Add a sentence after the joke: Instead of “I’m not attacking you, I’m just joking (seriously),” say something like **“I meant to say it comfortably.”**

items.title: 2) Chatting fatigue, ‘a lot of conversation but no conclusion’
items.when: We continued talking, but no plans/plans for the next meeting were decided and we dispersed.
items.why: Exploratory conversations can be fun when they're long, but when the 'organizing role' is empty, it only becomes tiring.
items.tip: Last 2 minutes only rule: **“1 conclusion for today + 1 thing to do next”**.

items.title: 3) When ‘request for empathy’ and ‘solution proposal’ conflict
items.when: When someone talks about a problem, someone talks about a solution first, and someone else does it from above.
items.why: If what the other person wants is ‘empathy’ or ‘solution’, even good intentions are translated into nagging/indifference.
items.tip: One starting question: **“Do you need empathy now? Do you need a solution?”**

sections.title: Trigger when awkwardness begins (be careful at this time)

items.title: When the line ‘What’s the problem with that?’
items.detail: The other person may not be talking about a problem, but rather ‘mood/context’. If you only push it with facts at this time, it will cool down quickly.

items.title: When ‘So what’s the conclusion?’ comes too quickly
items.detail: I'm still in the light-hearted chatting stage, but when pressure comes to conclude, I ask, "Am I being evaluated now?" I get a feeling.

items.title: When one person becomes quiet but no one checks
items.detail: Since friend groups are not ‘business’, people who become quiet go into a self-distance mode.

sections.title: What to watch out for: You can just remember this as DO / DON’T

do: **Summary** of what the other person said: “What you said is A, right?”
If you feel like arguing, **reveal standards**: “I spoke in terms of efficiency.”
The ending is **1 line of conclusion**: “Next time, let’s do ○○.”
dont: After the conversation, we disperse without deciding anything (only fatigue remains)

sections.title: 4 operating rules to make friend groups ‘comfortable’

items.title: Rule 1) Add ‘now stage’ in words
items.how: Conflicts can be reduced just by distinguishing between “now chatting (exploration) / now organizing (decision).”
items.example: “Okay, now is chat time! Let’s conclude in 10 minutes.”

items.title: Rule 2) Only one line in conclusion
items.how: Don’t be as long as meeting minutes, just leave one line at the end.
items.example: “Today’s conclusion: Next time, 7 o’clock, location ○○.”

items.title: Rule 3) Empathy/Resolution Switch Question
items.how: When a concern comes up, there is one question I always ask first.
items.example: “Do you need empathy or a solution now?”

items.title: Rule 4) ‘Fix the target’ when words can sound strong
items.how: At moments when it can easily sound like an evaluation of a person, focus only on the result/situation.
items.example: Not “You are the problem,” but “This situation became tangled.”

sections.title: ‘Alternative sentences’ for each situation (words that can be used as is)

items.situation: When a joke turns into a misunderstanding
items.say: “I’m sorry if I misunderstood you. My intention was to speak in a relaxed manner.”
items.instead: “Oh, what happened” (this can quickly escalate the situation)

items.situation: When the other person talks about their feelings and I go into solution mode
items.say: “Should empathy come first now? Or shall we find a solution together?”

items.situation: When the conversation goes on without end
items.say: “Okay, then let’s conclude with just one conclusion.”

sections.title: Frequently Asked Questions

items.q: If you have the same MBTI, is it always easy to meet up with friends?
items.a: Not necessarily. Even among people with the same style, if you push the same standard too hard, it can actually lead to a war of nerves. Convenience is often determined by ‘operating rules’ rather than ‘equality’.

items.q: What's the quickest thing to do when things get awkward?
items.a: “I’m sorry if I misunderstood. That was my intention.” This one sentence. When the emotional fight turns into ‘confirmation of intention’, it quickly resolves.

title: When a friend group takes ‘two weeks just to make an appointment’
description: The group chat is noisy, but the date/location is not decided until the end. The rule is not ‘who procrastinates’ but ‘why the structure can’t make a decision’.

sections.title: TOP 3 friend meeting patterns where you can't make a decision

items.title: 1) Collect only ‘available days’ and do not make selections
items.when: Everyone says what days they can, but no one ‘picks one’.
items.why: The possibilities are endless when you mix opinion gathering (exploration) and selection (convergence) in the same chat.
items.tip: **Separated into 24 hours of exploration → 2 hours of convergence**: “It is possible until 9 o’clock tomorrow, and then I will narrow it down to 2 and vote.”

items.title: 2) ‘Place’ turns into a battle of tastes
items.when: They say ‘anywhere’ and when a candidate comes up, they say they don’t like it.
items.why: If the criteria are hidden, candidates will continue to be eliminated (price/distance/atmosphere).
items.tip: Only 3 criteria revealed: **Distance/Budget/Atmosphere (Quiet/Activity)**

items.title: 3) When I make a decision, I don’t like the feeling of being in charge.
items.when: Everyone sneaks out for fear that there will be dissatisfaction if someone decides.
items.why: If a decision is perceived as a responsibility, no one will take charge of the process.
items.tip: Reduce the burden of progress to ‘experimentation’: **“Let’s go for a test this time and if it’s not good, let’s change it next time.”**

sections.title: From this point on, the group chat is broken.

items.title: When ‘anywhere’ is repeated more than 3 times
items.detail: Anywhere = This is a sign that the standards have not been made public yet.

items.title: When every time there is one candidate, only opposition runs.
items.detail: Opposition is easy, but if there is no alternative, fatigue only builds up.

items.title: When a diver comes out just before the schedule is confirmed
items.detail: People who feel that confirmation is ‘constraint’ fall into that timing.

sections.title: DO/DON’T

do: The decision is made by voting on two options.
dont: Return to the starting point before confirmation

sections.title: 4 operating rules to speed up appointments

items.title: Rule 1) Up to two candidates
items.example: “Let’s choose only two: A (quiet) and B (active).”

items.title: Rule 2) The person in charge of progress is not the ‘decider’ but the ‘organizer’
items.how: If you just take charge of organizing, the burden is greatly reduced.
items.example: “I’ll just organize it. The choice is made by voting.”

items.title: Rule 3) Voting must have a deadline
items.how: Without a deadline, voting turns into a conversation.
items.example: “Closes at 10 o’clock today. Non-response will be counted as a majority!”

items.title: Rule 4) Complaints will be reflected in the next round
items.how: Don't wake up today with today's dissatisfaction.
items.example: “Let’s go like this this time, and next time, let’s reflect your taste.”

sections.title: Group chat sentences that can be copied and pasted as is

items.say: “Only until 9 o’clock tomorrow! After that, I will reduce the number to two and raise the vote.”
“Only two candidates, A/B. One vote each! One line of reason.”
“Okay, let’s reflect that in the next episode. It’s confirmed for today!”

sections.title: FAQ

items.q: I think only the person in charge of progress is at a loss.
items.a: So, the key is to separate the process manager into ‘organizing’ and the selection into ‘voting’.

items.q: It keeps breaking because of divers.
items.a: If you add a majority rule for deadline + non-response, diving becomes ‘delegation’ rather than ‘interference’.

title: When friend groups become subtle in ‘money talk’
description: Settlement, Dutch, prepayment, membership fee… Minor money issues can drastically change the temperature of a relationship. Rather than ‘who paid more,’ we sorted out the problems that arise because ‘there are no rules.’

sections.title: TOP 3 patterns that become subtle because of money

items.title: 1) Settlement where ‘let’s do it later’ doesn’t work out in the end
items.when: The day passed, but after a few days, it became difficult to talk about it.
items.why: As time passes, settlement becomes a ‘people’ issue rather than a ‘money’ issue.
items.tip: Finishing on the spot: **“Just settle for 30 seconds now and let’s go cleanly.”**

items.title: 2) When ‘prepayment’ becomes an implicit sacrifice
items.when: The same person always pays first and cannot speak later.
items.why: Prepayment = When consideration accumulates, it is misunderstood as ‘obviousness’.
items.tip: Turning rule: **“Today is A, next time is B”** in public.

items.title: 3) When differences in taste are translated into ‘unfairness’
items.when: Some people have expensive menus, while others have menus that they don't eat.
items.why: When the joint payment structure creates a ‘perceived loss,’ emotions build up.
items.tip: Separate items: **Common (Primary) + Personal (Additional)**.

sections.title: At this time, the temperature of the relationship drops.

items.title: When talking about settlement is only a ‘joke’
items.detail: The joke is not about solving the problem, but about putting it off.

items.title: When you calculate in your head, ‘I paid more’
items.detail: From that moment on, the meeting becomes a ‘book’ rather than a ‘relationship’.

items.title: When uploading the settlement app/account link late
items.detail: The longer it is late, the more embarrassing it will be for the sender.

sections.title: DO/DON’T

dont: The same person always pays first

sections.title: 4 operating rules to prevent money problems from becoming a problem

items.title: Rule 1) ‘Same-day settlement’ is the default
items.how: As time goes by, the difficulty of getting the word out increases.
items.example: “Let’s settle the bill right here today and let’s go.”

items.title: Rule 2) Prepayment is on a sequential basis.
items.example: “A did it today, so next time B will do it.”

items.title: Rule 3) Separation of common/private expenses
items.example: “Basic is 1/N, additional is for those who ate.”

items.title: Rule 4) Membership fees are ‘clear range’
items.how: Ambiguous membership fees lead to dissatisfaction.
items.example: “The membership fee only covers the location/snacks, and each person takes a taxi.”

sections.title: Sentences that make settlement not awkward

items.say: “Let’s settle the bill right here today and let’s go!”
“I feel like I’m the only one who keeps making payments… so let’s do it in turns.”
“Let’s eat the basics together and split the extras between those who ate them.”

sections.title: FAQ

items.q: I'm afraid that if I talk about money, I'll look petty.
items.a: If you make the rules first, it’s less embarrassing because you end up talking about the ‘system’ rather than ‘people’.

items.q: Someone sends it late.
items.a: It’s good to set a deadline: “Please do it before lunch tomorrow!”

title: When a friend group suddenly becomes dangerous due to ‘talking behind one’s back’
description: At first it was a light chat, but later there were moments when it took a turn towards someone getting hurt. We have defined the boundary between ‘fun chat’ and ‘landmines.’

sections.title: TOP 3 patterns that turn into mines when you say things behind your back

items.title: 1) When ‘empathy’ is forced into ‘sympathy’
items.when: In the flow of criticizing someone, if you don’t agree, you become ‘Are you on that side too?’
items.why: The moment you try to confirm your belonging in a relationship, chatter becomes censored.
items.tip: Drawing a Line Sentence: **“I don’t know the situation, so I’ll reserve judgment.”**

items.title: 2) Personal attacks packaged as jokes
items.when: “It’s a joke~” Someone behind me has a hard expression.
items.why: When the subject matter is people, it sounds like ‘evaluation’ rather than laughter.
items.tip: Change object: person → situation. **“The situation” instead of “The person”**

items.title: 3) Risk of ‘spreading’ through group chat/story
items.when: I'm worried that someone might capture/forward it to me.
items.why: When there is a risk of transmission, trust in gatherings is rapidly broken.
items.tip: Safety Sentence: **“This is only here. Don’t let it go out.”**

sections.title: You better stop when you see this signal

items.title: When a person smiles but their eyes don't smile
items.detail: This may be the moment when laughter becomes ‘cheating.’

items.title: When a conversation is concluded without ‘checking the facts’
items.detail: Assertiveness divides relationships.

items.title: When “What do you think?” sounds like pressure
items.detail: It is an atmosphere where neutrality is not allowed.

sections.title: DO/DON’T

do: Move target from person to situation

sections.title: 4 rules to make chatting safe

items.title: Rule 1) Separation of ‘facts/interpretation/emotion’
items.example: “The facts are A, my interpretation is B, and my feelings are C.”

items.title: Rule 2) Evaluating people is prohibited
items.example: “That behavior wasn’t very good” is OK, “That person wasn’t very good” is NO.

items.title: Rule 3) Neutrality allowed
items.example: “If you don’t know, you can withhold judgment.”

items.title: Rule 4) No transmission of group chat
items.example: “Capturing/transmitting is prohibited. This ends here.”

sections.title: A sentence that draws a line without breaking the mood

items.say: “I don’t know the situation, so I’ll reserve judgment.”
“That might sound like an evaluation of a person… so let’s just talk about the situation.”

items.situation: When you are concerned about transmission
items.say: “Let’s just talk about this here. If we go out, it’ll be uncomfortable for both of us.”

sections.title: FAQ

items.q: Is chatting itself bad?
items.a: No. As long as you leave out the ‘evaluation/determination/dissemination of people’, chatting makes relationships closer.

items.q: What if the person who draws the line breaks the mood?
items.a: Fights will decrease if you say, “I’m not trying to break the mood, I’m putting in place a safety measure to make us more comfortable.”

title: How to avoid breaking the mood when a ‘new member’ joins a friend group
description: There are moments when the existing members are comfortable, but it is difficult for new people to join. If you are too considerate, it becomes awkward again. We have organized operating rules that blend in naturally.

sections.title: TOP 3 patterns that make new members awkward

items.title: 1) When running only on internal memes/memories
items.when: The existing members burst into laughter and the new members just laugh.
items.why: If you are ‘watching’ rather than ‘being together’, you will get tired.
items.tip: Memories are short, connecting questions: **“Have you had a similar experience?”**

items.title: 2) When excessive consideration is actually a burden
items.when: Keep asking “Are you okay?” “Isn’t it uncomfortable?” It's even more awkward because I checked.
items.why: When consideration feels like a ‘prosecution’, tension rises.
items.tip: Consideration of structure instead of direct checking: Move **seat/subject/turn** naturally.

items.title: 3) When a ‘who’s side’ game arises
items.when: There is no room for new members to come in between the existing members.
items.why: If the relationship is already solidified, the new member has no ‘position’.
items.tip: Short pairing: **2:2 conversation → shuffle to global sharing**.

sections.title: A new member is leaving at this time.

items.title: When the meme description appears 3 times in a row
items.detail: Explanation becomes a ‘lesson’ rather than participation.

items.title: When the conversation speed is too fast
items.detail: New members can't find the right time to intervene.

items.title: When there is a lot of skinship/slang only between existing members
items.detail: There is a clear sense of distance.

sections.title: DO/DON’T

dont: Ask new members questions like an interview

sections.title: 4 rules for new members to blend in naturally

items.title: Rule 1) Memories last only 30 seconds
items.how: If it gets longer, it becomes a sight to behold.
items.example: “Just briefly! This is what happened then and it’s over.”

items.title: Rule 2) 1 connecting question
items.how: Open the ‘door’ for new members to speak.
items.example: “What would you do in a situation like this?”

items.title: Rule 3) Pairing 10 minutes
items.how: It’s less stressful than a full conversation.
items.example: “Let’s talk 2:2 for 10 minutes and then get back together.”

items.title: Rule 4) Introduction is more about ‘taste’ than ‘information’
items.how: You become closer to your tastes faster than your job/specs.
items.example: “What are you into these days?”

sections.title: Sentences that make new members feel comfortable

items.say: “This is a meme between us… Do you like this style?”

items.situation: When a new member is quiet
items.say: “What is the most fun thing for you these days?”
“Relax! Let’s just talk about your preferences.”

sections.title: FAQ

items.q: The new member is very shy.
items.a: A 1:1 or 2:2 conversation is much more comfortable than a full conversation. The fastest way is to change the structure.

items.q: The existing members say it’s ‘originally our style’ and they don’t want to change it.
items.a: If you say, “I’m not asking for change, but rather a device to make it easier for new people,” resistance will decrease.

title: When company meetings/meetings keep falling into place
description: I have a meeting, but when it's over, it feels like there's nothing left. We have organized a structure where decisions cannot be made and words/rules for reaching conclusions without breaking the team spirit.

sections.title: TOP 3 patterns that frequently occur in company meetings

items.title: 1) A meeting with more options but no choices
items.when: ‘Good ideas’ keep coming, but decisions are delayed.
items.why: If standards are not shared, no conclusion can be reached even if everyone says the right thing.
items.tip: One line at the start of the meeting: “Today, let’s decide **speed first**.”

items.title: 2) The moment feedback is heard as ‘human evaluation’
items.when: Even though we’re talking about the results, the other person’s expression hardens.
items.why: The shorter the expression, the more likely it is to be translated as ‘attack.’
items.tip: Target fixation: “This sentence/this schedule/this condition” instead of “you.”

items.title: 3) Absence of organization manager
items.when: At the end of the meeting, “So what did we decide to do?”
items.why: Without a concluding sentence, the meeting is consumed only as a ‘conversation’.
items.tip: Last minute: **1 conclusion + 2 actions (responsibilities/due dates)**

sections.title: It's the most confusing at this time.

items.title: When you go back to the beginning just before making a decision
items.detail: If you don't redefine the standard/range, it goes into an infinite loop.

items.title: ‘That’s not it… When only ’ increases
items.detail: There is a lot of opposition, but if there is no alternative, emotions only build up.

sections.title: DO/DON’T

do: The target of feedback is the result
dont: Just oppose and end it without an alternative.

sections.title: 3 meeting rules that work right away

items.title: Rule 1) 10 minutes exploration → 10 minutes convergence
Rule 2) Forced reduction to A/B
items.how: If there are more than three options, the conclusion will be delayed.

items.title: Rule 3) 1 conclusion + 2 actions
items.how: Even if you leave only the ‘conclusion’ instead of the meeting minutes, the next thing will be different.

sections.title: Words that come to a conclusion without breaking the team spirit

items.situation: When there are too many options
items.say: “Okay, then let’s reduce it to just A/B and decide here for today.”

items.situation: When you are worried that the feedback will be too strong
items.say: “I will only talk about results, not people.”

sections.title: FAQ

items.q: In conclusion, I feel like someone loses out.
items.a: Then, if you replace ‘decision’ with ‘two-week experiment’, the conflict will be significantly reduced.

title: When a meeting ends with only a few people speaking
description: A team where only the talkative people keep talking, and the quiet people speak separately after the meeting. How to reduce the variation in speaking volume through ‘rules’ rather than ‘people problems’.

sections.title: TOP 3 patterns that cause speech deviations

items.title: 1) People with quick reactions control the flow of the meeting
items.when: Someone comes to a conclusion before I can organize my thoughts.
items.why: When impromptu remarks are interpreted as ‘leadership’, quiet people become more silent.
items.tip: 30 second silence rule: **“After asking a question, 30 seconds is time to think”**

items.title: 2) The question sounds like a ‘judgment’ rather than an ‘opinion’
items.when: It's a question, but it feels like an interrogation.
items.why: If the question sounds evaluative, defenses go up, and only safe people speak.
items.tip: Change the question frame: **“Let’s find the risks in this together”**

items.title: 3) Opinions of quiet people are pushed to ‘later’
items.when: I can't speak during meetings, so I can only express my opinions through DM.
items.why: If a meeting only allows ‘real-time discussion’, thinking types are excluded.
items.tip: Pre-entered 3 lines: **Receive 3 lines of ‘opinions/risks/alternatives’ before the meeting**

sections.title: When this signal comes out, we need to change the structure.

items.title: When important opinions are only expressed after a meeting
items.detail: Meetings have become ‘a space only for speakers.’

items.title: When there are almost no opposing opinions
items.detail: It may not be agreement, but silence.

items.title: When remarks are evaluated centered on ‘people’
items.detail: Psychological safety decreases.

sections.title: DO/DON’T

dont: Assuming quiet people are ‘lack of participation’

sections.title: 4 rules for balancing speech

items.title: Rule 1) 30 seconds silence after question
items.how: Prevents fast people from driving alone.
items.example: “Just think for 30 seconds and say one line at a time.”

items.title: Rule 2) One-line remarks in rounds
items.example: “Each person in one line, full/half/condition only.”

items.title: Rule 3) Opposite is set with ‘alternative’
items.how: It prevents opposition from building up.
items.example: “On the other hand, there is one alternative.”

items.title: Rule 4) Recap 10 minutes after meeting
items.example: “We will accept additional comments for 10 minutes after the end.”

sections.title: Words that make the team less uncomfortable

items.situation: When you see a solo drink
items.say: “Okay. This time, let’s listen to each line in rounds and put them back together.”

items.situation: When you are worried that your question will sound too strong
items.say: “It’s not a question of evaluation, but a question of finding risks together.”

sections.title: FAQ

items.q: There are times when quiet people really have no opinions, right?
items.a: Therefore, it is better to keep the ‘pre/post-input’ channel open, rather than ‘remarks during the meeting’.

items.q: Round remarks are awkward.
items.a: If you only allow ‘one line’ at first, the burden is greatly reduced.

title: When decisions are delayed because they feel like they have to be ‘perfect’
description: A team that loses speed while trying to reduce risk. This is not to abandon perfectionism, but it is a way to ‘stage’ perfection so that the team can safely become faster.

sections.title: TOP 3 patterns of delayed decisions

items.title: 1) Wait until 100% of information is gathered
items.when: They keep requesting additional data and the conclusions are pushed back.
items.why: When gathering information feels ‘safe’, decisions are put off forever.
items.tip: Declaration of Sufficient Conditions: **“With the information I have now, I decide to experiment for two weeks”**

items.title: 2) Teams whose opposition appears to be ‘avoiding responsibility’
items.when: If you express a dissenting opinion, you will be branded as ‘ankle’.
items.why: When opposition becomes dangerous, the team agrees to silence (more risk).
items.tip: Rule to encourage opposition: **“One opposition is the team’s insurance”**

items.title: 3) Mistaking the decision as ‘permanent’
items.when: I feel like once I decide on something, I can’t change it again.
items.why: When a decision becomes as hard as a stone, everyone gets scared.
items.tip: Decision=Version: **V1 (2 weeks) → V2 (1 month)**

sections.title: By the time these words come out, it's already too late

items.title: When “Find out more…” is repeated
items.detail: This is the moment when further investigation becomes an end in itself.

items.title: When “Who is responsible?” comes before the conclusion.
items.detail: It becomes a game of punishment avoidance rather than a decision.

items.title: When the approval line is long even for small decisions
items.detail: Speed breaks down from the structure.

sections.title: DO/DON’T

do: The decision is made by version.

sections.title: 4 rules to make decisions faster

items.title: Rule 1) Decide with V1
items.how: Don't demand perfection from the start.
items.example: “You can change V1 after using it for two weeks.”

items.title: Rule 2) Risk has only an ‘upper limit’
items.example: “How much damage will there be in the worst case?”

items.title: Rule 3) Opposition as ‘alternative/condition’
items.example: “I am against it, but I agree with this condition.”

items.title: Rule 4) Post a review on the calendar after execution
items.example: “Review meeting confirmed in two weeks.”

sections.title: Words for safely speeding up a perfectionist team

items.situation: The trend of gathering more information
items.say: “Okay. Then, with the current information, we will only decide on V1 (2-week experiment), and any additional information will be reflected in V2.”
“The opposite is insurance for the team. Instead, please also provide alternatives/conditions.”

sections.title: FAQ

items.q: What if the experiment fails?
items.a: That’s why we first set the ‘risk limit’. Controlling the cost of failure makes experiments safer.

title: As feedback accumulates, the cold war of the team that ‘doesn’t say anything’
description: A team that is quiet in meetings, but whose complaints only leak out behind the scenes. We have organized devices that change feedback from being a battle between people to a ‘fight for results.’

sections.title: Feedback Cold War Pattern TOP 3

items.title: 1) ‘It’s okay’ is actually not okay
items.when: The expression doesn't say anything, but the words say it's okay.
items.why: If I speak directly, I am afraid that the relationship will break down, so I make a ‘tolerating agreement’.
items.tip: Change the check question: **“What is your score from 0 to 10?”** (Specification)

items.title: 2) Feedback is heard as ‘evaluation’
items.when: Requests for corrections are treated like personal attacks.
items.why: When objects (people/products) are mixed, the defense goes up.
items.tip: Target fixation: First declare **“Only based on results”**

items.title: 3) Issues circulate only through DM/backdoor messages
items.when: I can't speak in meetings and only complain in personal chat.
items.why: If official channels are not secure, unofficial channels will grow.
items.tip: Rule: **Collect ‘anonymous risk’ 5 minutes after the end of the meeting**

sections.title: From this point on, the Cold War deepened.

items.title: When ‘intentional’ attacks start to emerge
items.detail: “You did that on purpose, right?” Same sentence.

items.title: When feedback flows through ‘human tendencies’
items.detail: It becomes a battle of personalities rather than a story of results.

items.title: When dissatisfaction only explodes after a meeting
items.detail: This is a sign that the official channel is empty.

sections.title: DO/DON’T
4 rules to prevent a cold war

items.title: Rule 1) Feedback is ‘Observation→Influence→Suggestion’
items.example: “When I look at A, I see B, so why not change it to C?”

items.title: Rule 2) First with a score of 0 to 10
items.example: “What is your score now?”

items.title: Rule 3) Risk is anonymous 5 minutes
items.example: “Anonymously, take only one risk each.”

items.title: Rule 4) Agreement is concluded with ‘one line of conclusion’
items.example: “Today’s conclusion: go with A, and complement risk B with C.”

sections.title: Sentences that make feedback sound less painful

items.situation: When it's hard to say something
items.say: “I will only talk about results, not people.”

items.situation: When an ambiguous ‘It’s okay’ comes out
items.say: “If the score is 0 to 10, what is the score? If it is 7 or less, there is only one line of improvement.”

sections.title: FAQ

items.q: Wouldn’t collecting anonymous risks make the atmosphere worse?
items.a: On the contrary, when opposition is made ‘official’, there are many cases where backbiting decreases and the team temperature stabilizes.

title: When words are read ‘coldly’ in messenger/asynchronous work
description: The intention is to deal with the situation quickly, but the opponent feels it is an attack. We have compiled sentences/rules to reduce misunderstandings in asynchronous communication.

sections.title: TOP 3 Misunderstood Patterns in Asynchronous

items.title: 1) Short sentences are read as ‘commands’
items.when: Sentences like “fix this” and “until today” feel cold.
items.why: The text has no expression/tone, so the shorter it is, the stronger it becomes.
items.tip: Add only 1 buffer: **1 line of context + 1 line of request**

items.title: 2) Confirmation questions sound like ‘censorship’
items.when: “Why did you do this?” seems like an attack.
items.why: If the intent (curiosity/quality) is not shared, it becomes an interrogation.
items.tip: Intention first: **“This is a quality check question”**

items.title: 3) Late reply = translated as ignored
items.when: If I don't have an answer, I feel like the other person is ignoring me.
items.why: In asynchronous, the absence of ‘waiting rules’ increases the emotion.
items.tip: SLA agreement: **“Response within 4 hours, @mention if urgent”**

sections.title: When this signal comes out, communication is broken.

items.title: When talk about ‘tone of speech’ starts to come up
items.detail: It's not about work, but about emotional battles.

items.title: When you look aggressive only on messenger
items.detail: This is a misunderstanding that would not occur if it were offline.

items.title: When checking/re-checking is excessive
items.detail: When trust is shaken, the text becomes sharper.

sections.title: DO/DON’T

dont: Interpreting late answers as a reflection of personality

sections.title: 4 rules to reduce asynchronous misunderstandings

items.title: Rule 1) 1 line of context + 1 line of request
items.example: “I’m checking because of my schedule. Please do it before 5 o’clock today.”

items.title: Rule 2) Intention tag in questions
items.how: It sounds like collaboration, not interrogation.
items.example: “What was the intention of this part (quality check)?”

items.title: Rule 3) Response SLA agreement
items.example: “Answer within 4 hours, @ if you’re in a hurry.”

items.title: Rule 4) Call for sensitive things
items.example: “This could cause some misunderstanding, so can we just talk for 5 minutes?”

sections.title: Alternative sentences that don't sound cold

items.say: “I’m checking because of the schedule. Can it be reflected before 5 o’clock today?”

items.situation: When you want to ask why you did this
items.say: “(Confirmation of intent) I’m curious about the background of this choice. This is a quality check question.”

items.situation: Prompt when the answer is late
items.say: “It’s not urgent, so please answer when it’s comfortable. Can you do it today?”

sections.title: FAQ

items.q: Wouldn't it be too long if I added context?
items.a: Even if you add just one line, the tone you feel will become significantly softer. If the ‘why’ is visible, it is less likely to be read as an attack.

title: When neighborhood gatherings become uncomfortable due to ‘kindness that crosses the line’
description: It's comfortable because it's close, but the neighborhood relationship becomes more sensitive because it's close. We have organized the ‘distance control’ rule to prevent trivial words and actions from turning into misunderstandings.

sections.title: TOP 3 patterns that frequently occur at neighborhood gatherings

items.title: 1) The moment favor turns into ‘obligation’
items.when: If you help once, expectations will arise as if it were a given from the next time.
items.why: When distances and living areas overlap, small favors are repeated and standards become solid.
items.tip: Favors come with conditions: **“It’s possible this time. Next time, we have to see the situation.”**

items.title: 2) When personal information is shared too quickly
items.when: Personal circumstances unintentionally spread throughout the group.
items.why: The neighborhood is tightly connected, so ‘light talk’ can easily become a rumor.
items.tip: One-sentence prevention line: **“This is not finalized yet, so please be quiet.”**

items.title: 3) Even though we have become close friends, our ‘sensitive points’ are different.
items.when: It was a joke, but it was hurtful, or the advice sounded like interference.
items.why: As closeness builds, words become shorter and interpretations become stronger.
items.tip: Target fixation: **Speaking only of the situation/behavior, not evaluating the person**.

sections.title: When this signal appears, you need to adjust the distance.

items.title: When you start saying “I can do that much”
items.detail: This is a sign that favors will turn into transactions.

items.title: When a light request turns into a ‘same-day’ request
items.detail: The other person is starting to perceive my time as ‘free.’

items.title: When people talk about me often when I'm not around
items.detail: This is the moment when personal information becomes the subject of a meeting.

sections.title: DO/DON’T

do: When it comes to favors, say the **possible range** first.
Sort out inconveniences **shortly** at the beginning.
dont: Hold it in and explode all at once
Pushing advice as if it were the ‘right answer’
Consuming the other person’s private life like gossip

sections.title: 4 operating rules to make neighborhood gatherings easier

items.title: Rule 1) Offer requests as ‘optional’
items.how: Making your request a choice rather than a command reduces the burden.
items.example: “If possible, help, and if it’s difficult, let’s find another way.”

items.title: Rule 2) When it comes to private life, only share ‘confirmed information’
items.how: Information before confirmation is likely to spread into rumors.
items.example: “I’ll tell you when it’s confirmed.”

items.title: Rule 3) Favor is default ‘just this time’
items.how: This is a basic sentence that prevents repetition expectations.
items.example: “It’s possible this time. Next time, I’ll have to look at the schedule.”

items.title: Rule 4) Only express discomfort through ‘actions’
items.how: Instead of talking about personality, just talk about actions/situations to avoid fights.
items.example: “That sounded like a burden to me.”

sections.title: Sentences that can be written as is

items.situation: When the request becomes too much
items.say: “I think it will be difficult this time because my schedule is difficult right now. Let’s find another way together.”

items.situation: When you are worried about your personal life being spread
items.say: “This isn’t finalized yet, so I’d like you to just talk about it here.”

items.situation: When favor becomes an expectation of repetition
items.say: “I want to help, but it’s always difficult and sometimes I can.”

sections.title: FAQ

items.q: Doesn’t it become awkward if you keep your distance?
items.a: In fact, things break faster when there are no standards. If you set the standard in words, the ‘structure’ rather than the ‘relationship’ is organized.

title: When neighborhood meetings are delayed due to ‘notices/decisions’
description: The reason there is a lot of talk about meetings but no conclusion is mostly due to the ‘decision structure’ rather than the ‘who’. We have compiled a consensus routine that is fast and hassle-free.

sections.title: TOP 3 patterns of delayed decisions

items.title: 1) Do not make a choice even after collecting opinions
items.when: There are a lot of complaints, but I can’t decide what to do next.
items.why: Everyone takes a step back because choices feel like responsibilities.
items.tip: Automate your decisions with **Vote + Deadline**.

items.title: 2) Candidates continue to be eliminated because the criteria are hidden
items.when: As candidates for location/time emerge, only the opposition runs one by one.
items.why: This is because ‘true standards’ such as distance, cost, and noise are not disclosed.
items.tip: First 3 criteria: **Time/Cost/Noise (Civil Complaint)**

items.title: 3) The notice text is long, so no one reads it.
items.when: Even though it is important information, there is no response.
items.why: Long announcements reduce engagement and increase questions.
items.tip: Notice Template: **One Line Summary + Date/Location + To Do**

sections.title: From this point on, fatigue increases.

items.title: When the same question is repeated 3 times
items.detail: The notice structure is long or the main point is not visible.

items.title: When there is only opposition and no alternative
items.detail: It's not an opinion, it's a distraction.

items.title: When returning to ‘origin’ just before a decision
items.detail: The scope/criteria need to be re-anchored.

sections.title: DO/DON’T
4 operating rules to make decisions faster

items.title: Rule 1) There are only two candidates, A/B.
items.how: The more choices you have, the slower the conclusion.
items.example: “This week only A (day) vs. B (night).”

items.title: Rule 2) Voting must end.
items.how: Without a deadline, voting turns into a conversation.
items.example: “Closed at 10 o’clock today, majority decision for non-response.”

items.title: Rule 3) Opposite is set with alternative
items.example: “On the other hand, there is one alternative.”

items.title: Rule 4) Notices are 3-line templates
items.how: Notices that are read are executed.
items.example: “Summary/Date/To-Do”

sections.title: Copy and paste sentences for notice/decision purposes

items.say: “Just give us your opinion by 9 o’clock tomorrow. After that, we will reduce it to A/B and post a vote.”
“Closes at 10 o’clock today. Non-response will be decided by majority vote.”
“Give opposition with an alternative. That way, a choice can be made.”

sections.title: FAQ

items.q: When I make a decision, I become dissatisfied.
items.a: So, if you change the frame from ‘permanent decision’ to ‘this round of testing’, conflict will be reduced.

title: When neighborhood group dues/settlement becomes ‘subtly’ inconvenient
description: The issue of membership fees is difficult to talk about because it is a small amount. Before it spreads to people's fault, I've organized a way to organize it with rules.

sections.title: TOP 3 patterns where membership fees become subtle

items.title: 1) ‘Once you collect it’, it changes to distrust of how it will be used.
items.when: The money was saved, but it was late to share where it was spent.
items.why: Information gaps increase suspicion.
items.tip: 3 lines published once a month: **Balance/Where used/Next plan**

items.title: 2) Same membership fee although participation frequency is different
items.when: People who come often and people who come sometimes pay the same amount.
items.why: When perceived fairness is broken, relationships become cold.
items.tip: Dualization: **Basic membership fee + attendee fee (same day)**

items.title: 3) Someone keeps ‘paying back’
items.when: There's always one person who pays for me and doesn't say anything.
items.why: If payments accumulate, it becomes a burden rather than consideration.
items.tip: Serial system + deadline: **“A this month, B next month”**

sections.title: Signs that relationship temperature is dropping

items.title: When the topic of membership fees is only a joke
items.detail: Because jokes are not a solution, but a procrastination.

items.title: When receipt/statement sharing changes to ‘request’
items.detail: This means that trust is already being shaken.

items.title: When borrowers begin to withdraw quietly
items.detail: This is the stage where you express your dissatisfaction with actions instead of words.

sections.title: DO/DON’T

do: Share details regularly, even if briefly
dont: Receive payment as a matter of course

sections.title: 4 rules to keep membership fees clean

items.title: Rule 1) Details are ‘regular’
items.how: Disclosure before being asked reduces conflict.
items.example: “At the end of each month, share 3 lines of balance/usage.”

items.title: Rule 2) Separate basic/day expenses
items.example: “Basically, it is shared, and on the day, it is calculated by attendees.”

items.title: Rule 3) Payment is in order.
items.how: Distributes the burden across the system.
items.example: “This month A, next month B.”

items.title: Rule 4) Non-payment is due.
items.how: End non-payment before it becomes a relationship problem.
items.example: “Please do me a favor before noon tomorrow.”

sections.title: Sentence for membership fees/settlement

items.say: “I am sharing this month’s membership fee details. Balance / usage / next plan is as follows.”
“To be fair, how about dividing it into basic membership fee + daily cost?”
“It’s a burden if the payments accumulate, so from now on, let’s use a sequential system.”

sections.title: FAQ

items.q: Talking about money breaks the mood.
items.a: When you create rules, you’re talking about the ‘system’ rather than ‘people’, so it’s much less inconvenient.

title: How to stop chatting at neighborhood gatherings before it turns into a ‘rumour’
description: Since the neighborhood is close, once it spreads, it is difficult to reverse. We've put together safety measures to prevent chatting from destroying relationships.

sections.title: TOP 3 patterns that make chatting dangerous

items.title: 1) Conclusion without verifying facts
items.when: Once you hear something, it becomes solid as a ‘fact.’
items.why: Assertions are easily conveyed, corrections are difficult.
items.tip: Preface: **“That’s all I heard”**

items.title: 2) Friendship confirmation game
items.when: If you disagree, it becomes ‘Are you on that side?’
items.why: This is the moment when chatter turns into censorship of belonging.
items.tip: Neutral Sentence: **“I’ll reserve judgment.”**

items.title: 3) Jokes that cross the line
items.when: Something meant to be funny can become a stigma to someone else.
items.why: Neighborhoods are more sensitive because their reputation is an asset.
items.tip: Change the object: **just the situation, not the person**

sections.title: Turn when you see this signal

items.title: Specific information such as name/family/workplace begins to appear.
items.detail: From that moment on, the risk of transmission skyrockets.

items.title: “What do you think?” comes across as pressure.
items.detail: It is an atmosphere where neutrality is not allowed.

items.title: When talking about capture/delivery
items.detail: Trust is already being shaken.

sections.title: DO/DON’T
4 rules to make chatting safe

items.title: Rule 1) Fact/Interpretation/Emotion Separation
items.example: “The facts are A, my interpretation is B, and my feeling is C.”

items.title: Rule 2) Evaluating people is prohibited
items.example: “That behavior is not that good” is allowed, “That person is not that good” is prohibited.

items.title: Rule 3) Neutrality allowed
items.example: “If you don’t know, you can withhold judgment.”

items.title: Rule 4) Check sharing range
items.how: The rate of spread is fast in the neighborhood.
items.example: “Let’s just talk about this here.”

sections.title: A sentence that draws a line without breaking the mood

items.say: “I don’t know exactly about that, so I’ll reserve judgment.”
“It may sound like an evaluation of a person, so let’s just talk about the situation.”
“Let’s just talk about this here. If we go out, it’ll be uncomfortable for both of us.”

sections.title: FAQ

items.q: They say that the person who draws the line breaks the mood.
items.a: Conflicts are reduced if you say, “I’m not trying to break the mood, but I’m putting in place safety measures to make us more comfortable.”

title: How to reduce ‘awkwardness’ when a new person joins a neighborhood gathering
description: The neighborhood already has a strong network of relationships, so new members are more cautious. We organized a structure that blends naturally without excessive consideration.

sections.title: TOP 3 patterns that make new members awkward

items.title: 1) Only internal discussion continues
items.when: Apartment/neighborhood incidents, there are many contexts that only existing members know about.
items.why: If the explanation is long, the new member will be ‘listening’ rather than ‘participating’.
items.tip: 30 seconds of context, 1 connecting question: **“Have you ever been in this situation?”**

items.title: 2) Check excessive condition
items.when: I get more nervous by repeating “Isn’t it uncomfortable?”
items.why: If consideration feels like inspection, less will be said.
items.tip: Consider structure instead of checking: rotating **seats/turns/subjects**.

items.title: 3) New member has no ‘position’
items.when: It is difficult to join in because the partner has already been decided.
items.why: Once you enter a place where relationships are solid, the role is not empty.
items.tip: Short pairing: **10 minutes 2:2 conversation → Full sharing**

sections.title: A new member is leaving at this time.

items.title: When the explanation is as long as a lesson
items.detail: New members lose their opportunity to speak.

items.title: When speech is interrupted frequently and the pace is fast
items.detail: I can't find the right time to intervene.

items.title: When only new members are asked questions
items.detail: The introduction becomes like an interview.

sections.title: DO/DON’T
4 rules for new members to blend in naturally

items.title: Rule 1) Memories/internal stories 30 seconds
items.how: If it gets longer, it becomes a sight to behold.
items.example: “Let’s keep it short and listen to your experience.”

items.title: Rule 2) 1 connecting question
items.how: It opens the door to speech.
items.example: “What would you do in a situation like this?”

items.title: Rule 3) Pairing 10 minutes
items.how: It’s less stressful than a full conversation.
items.example: “Let’s talk 2:2 for 10 minutes and then get back together.”

items.title: Rule 4) Introduction is taste-centered
items.how: You will become familiar with tastes faster than specifications.
items.example: “What are you interested in these days?”

sections.title: Introduction/adaptation sentences

items.say: “This is our own context. Do you have a similar experience?”

items.situation: When a new member is quiet
items.say: “What is the most fun thing these days?”

items.situation: When there are a lot of questions
items.say: “Let’s take it easy and just talk about tastes today.”

sections.title: FAQ

items.q: Isn’t it more difficult for people who are shy?
items.a: So a 1:1 or 2:2 structure is much more effective than a full conversation. The structure is considerate.

title: When exercise groups become increasingly uncomfortable due to ‘difference in intensity’
description: When people who work hard and people who exercise lightly mix, it becomes more tiring than the exercise itself. How to match intensity with ‘structure’ rather than ‘skill’.

sections.title: TOP 3 intensity mismatch patterns

items.title: 1) Different goals but grouped into the same session
items.when: For some, it's for recording, for others it's for relieving stress.
items.why: If the goals are different, the same training is interpreted differently as ‘good/pain’.
items.tip: Separate sessions: **Basic Course (Common) + Elective Course (Additional)**

items.title: 2) People with a fast pace are the standard.
items.when: Some people get exhausted trying to keep up with fast people.
items.why: When a leader inadvertently sets the standard, others follow in silence.
items.tip: The criteria is ‘medium’: **medium pace + additional rounds for fast groups**

items.title: 3) ‘Advice’ sounds intelligent
items.when: Words that were meant to help end up hurting.
items.why: When it comes to exercise, self-esteem is at stake, so expressions are sensitive.
items.tip: Permission and advice: **“Can I give you some advice?”**

sections.title: When this signal comes out, we need to change the structure.

items.title: When you still feel bad after exercising
items.detail: You may be exhausted from ‘noticing’ rather than exercising.

items.title: When only the fast people have fun and the rest are quiet
items.detail: The standards have been tilted to one side.

items.title: When advice becomes more frequent and responses decrease
items.detail: This is a stage that can be read as evaluation rather than help.

sections.title: DO/DON’T
4 operating rules to reduce intensity differences

items.title: Rule 1) Common 70% + Optional 30%
items.how: Separate work time from personal time.
items.example: “Warm up/basics together, choose afterward.”

items.title: Rule 2) Divide the group into ‘goals’
items.how: Goals are more important than skills.
items.example: Select “Records/Health/Friendship”.

items.title: Rule 3) Only give one piece of advice after permission.
items.how: If it is excessive, it sounds like an evaluation.
items.example: “Can I give you just one piece of advice?”

items.title: Rule 4) The end is together
items.example: “Everyone does the finishing stretch together.”

sections.title: Alternative sentences for each situation

items.say: “Let’s do the basic course together today, and if you want to do more, let’s go for the additional course.”

items.situation: When you want to give advice
items.say: “Can I give you some advice? If you don’t like it, just tell me.”

items.situation: When someone seems to be having a hard time
items.say: “That’s all for today, let’s adjust the pace next time.”

sections.title: FAQ

items.q: Wouldn’t friendship be broken if we split into groups?
items.a: If you share 70% in common, friendship will be maintained and conflict will be reduced.

title: When a sports meeting collapses due to ‘cancellation/non-attendance on the day’
description: In casual gatherings, there are no rules and they are broken more often. Instead of blaming people, we have outlined ways to change the ‘participation structure’.

sections.title: TOP 3 unauthorized absence/cancellation patterns

items.title: 1) Confirmation of attendance remains only a ‘feeling’
items.when: It is unclear whether “I will go” is a confirmation or an expression of intention.
items.why: If there are no set rules, there is no burden or responsibility.
items.tip: Unification of confirmed sentences: **“Confirmed/Pending/Cannot”** Only one of the three.

items.title: 2) Preparation costs (reservation/rental) apply, but there are no rules.
items.when: Some people spend money/time, while others get away with it.
items.why: When costs arise, the ‘lightness’ is broken and conflict arises.
items.tip: Deadline + penalty (small amount) rule: **“Cancellation after 10 o’clock the previous day is 1/n”**

items.title: 3) The schedule is set too far apart and the momentum is lost.
items.when: The promise made in two weeks is still psychologically ‘fake’.
items.why: The further away you are, the more variables there are and the more priorities there are.
items.tip: Create a Rhythm: **Fixed Day/Time**

sections.title: When this signal comes out, we need to change the structure.

items.title: When ‘sorry’ is repeated on the same day
items.detail: It has become a system problem rather than a personal problem.

items.title: When the prep staff starts to get tired
items.detail: The meeting is not maintained.

items.title: When only a few people consistently appear
items.detail: A free-riding structure may have emerged.

sections.title: DO/DON’T

dont: Burden only on those in charge of preparation
Due to the tendency to not attend without permission

sections.title: Four rules to reduce unauthorized absences

items.title: Rule 1) Attendance status in 3 levels
items.how: We manage with conditions, not words.
items.example: “Confirmed/Pending/Unavailable”

items.title: Rule 2) Deadline is required
items.how: If there is no deadline, it is not final.
items.example: “Closes at 10 o’clock the previous day”

items.title: Rule 3) Minimum rule if there is a cost
items.how: Even if it is only a small amount, there must be a standard.
items.example: “If you cancel after the deadline, the reservation fee is 1/n.”

items.title: Rule 4) Rhythm with fixed days
items.example: “Every Wednesday at 8 o’clock”

sections.title: Group chat copy and paste sentences

items.say: “This week, please only answer confirmed/pending/unavailable. The deadline is 10 o’clock the day before.”
“Because there is a rental/reservation, cancellation after the deadline will be charged 1/n.”
“How about going with a fixed day of the week to reduce variables?”

sections.title: FAQ

items.q: The penalty seems too stiff.
items.a: The purpose of the penalty is not punishment, but rather a safety measure to prevent burnout of the preparation staff.

title: When the skill gap is large and it becomes uncomfortable for the ‘teacher’ and the ‘learner’
description: There are times when one side wants to help, but the other side feels judged. How to organize coaching as a structure, not a relationship.

sections.title: TOP 3 patterns that are twisted due to skill differences

items.title: 1) Advice continues to accumulate
items.when: Once coaching starts, it doesn’t stop.
items.why: Help becomes a burden if it is repeated.
items.tip: Coaching is time-limited: **“Just 10 minutes today”**

items.title: 2) Only corrections without praise
items.when: Whenever I hear the words “fix”, my self-esteem goes down.
items.why: Exercise is all about the experience of accomplishment.
items.tip: Ratio: **1 compliment + 1 correction**

items.title: 3) The learner ‘continues to feel sorry’
items.when: Whenever I make a mistake, I pay attention to the atmosphere.
items.why: If a mistake is translated as a nuisance, the joy disappears.
items.tip: Changing the Framing of Mistakes: **“Practice is the time to make mistakes”**

sections.title: If you see this signal, you need to change your coaching structure.

items.title: When learners do not ask questions
items.detail: The burden has already increased.

items.title: When the teacher gets irritated
items.detail: Coaching has turned into a resource drain.

items.title: When the mood freezes after a mistake
items.detail: The goal of the meeting is not exercise, but awareness.

sections.title: DO/DON’T
4 rules to make coaching less uncomfortable

items.title: Rule 1) Coaching is requested
items.how: Without permission, it sounds like an evaluation.
items.example: “I’ll give you a tip if you want.”

items.title: Rule 2) 10 minute timer
items.how: Prevent excessive help from being provided.
items.example: “Just 10 minutes of coaching today.”

items.title: Rule 3) 1 compliment + 1 correction
items.example: “One thing I liked, one thing I would change.”

items.title: Rule 4) Mistakes are normal
items.example: “Mistakes are part of practice.”

sections.title: Coaching/Learning Sentences

items.situation: When you want to give advice
items.say: “Can I tell you a tip if you want?”
“Just do 10 minutes today and enjoy the rest.”
“It’s okay. Practice is a time to make mistakes.”

sections.title: FAQ

items.q: I think only those who teach are at a loss.
items.a: So, making coaching ‘request-based + time-bound’ distributes the burden.

title: When a sports group splits due to ‘the desire to win’
description: When people who want to win and people who want to have fun mix, even in the same game, they have different experiences. I've put together a rule that doesn't turn competitive spirit into negative feelings.

sections.title: TOP 3 competitive conflict patterns

items.title: 1) Criticism sounds like ‘criticism’ rather than ‘coaching’
items.when: When someone points out a mistake immediately after, their expression hardens.
items.why: During a game, emotions rise and sentences sound stronger.
items.tip: During the game, only signals: **short keywords**, feedback after the game.

items.title: 2) Responsibility is placed on a specific person
items.when: The moment I lose, my eyes fall on one person.
items.why: Team sports have a structure where it is easy to pass on responsibility.
items.tip: Speaking on a team basis: **“Next time, let’s focus on the defensive line.”**

items.title: 3) The atmosphere solidifies into ‘training’
items.when: It was a friendship, but gradually it became a place of evaluation.
items.why: When goals are not agreed upon, seriousness becomes conflict.
items.tip: Mode declaration: **Friendly War / Position Warfare** Separate

sections.title: When this signal appears, the mode must be divided.

items.title: When conversation decreases and facial expressions become stiff after the game.
items.detail: It is not a movement, but an emotional state.

items.title: When intelligence increases and laughter decreases
items.detail: The meeting is heading to the evaluation center.

items.title: When some keep coming and some fall out
items.detail: Goal discrepancy manifests itself in behavior.

sections.title: DO/DON’T
4 rules to prevent competition from becoming conflict

items.title: Rule 1) Separate friendly/position warfare
items.example: “Today is a friendly battle, next week is a serious battle.”

items.title: Rule 2) Feedback during the game is only signals.
items.example: Keywords like “line/distance/timing”.

items.title: Rule 3) Only 2 feedbacks after the game
items.how: If it goes too far, it sounds like an attack.
items.example: “1 thing I liked, 1 thing I would change.”

items.title: Rule 4) Responsibility lies with the team
items.example: “Next time, let’s coordinate our team movements.”

sections.title: Sentence to control competitive spirit

items.say: “Let’s go social today, and give it a serious try next time.”
“Let’s just give signals during the game. Let’s wrap things up after the feedback.”

items.situation: When it comes to personal responsibility
items.say: “This is not an individual issue, but a team movement issue.”

sections.title: FAQ

items.q: It's no fun if you take it seriously.
items.a: So ‘mode separation’ is the key. If you don't mix fun mode and training mode, you can save both.

title: When talking about ‘injury/safety’ at a sports meeting is uncomfortable
description: Safety rules do not stiffen the atmosphere, but are the bare minimum for long-term enjoyment. How to make safety an ‘agreement’ rather than a ‘nag’.

sections.title: TOP 3 patterns that lead to safety issues

items.title: 1) Warm-up/cooldown is omitted
items.when: Let's start right away because we don't have time.
items.why: As the gathering becomes more familiar, the basics are omitted.
items.tip: Fixed routine: **Start 5 minutes/End 5 minutes** absolutely.

items.title: 2) Hiding the pain and overdoing it
items.when: If I tell you I'm in pain, I feel like it's a nuisance, so I just put up with it.
items.why: If the meeting is focused on ‘strength’, it is difficult to talk about weakness.
items.tip: Consensus statement: **“Talking about pain is safe, not a nuisance”**

items.title: 3) Talk about equipment/protective gear is sensitive.
items.when: If you only ask someone to do it, it sounds like you're making a point.
items.why: When you make demands on people, their defenses go up.
items.tip: Rules, not people: **“Let’s set the meeting rules.”**

sections.title: When this signal appears, a rule must be entered immediately.

items.title: When small injuries are repeated
items.detail: This is most likely not a coincidence but a structural issue.

items.title: When a person who overdoes things is praised as a ‘virtue’
items.detail: This is where the safety culture is broken.

items.title: When warm-up exercises gradually decrease
items.detail: The probability of an accident increases.

sections.title: DO/DON’T

dont: Pain as a problem of will

sections.title: 4 rules to keep safe

items.title: Rule 1) Fixed start/end time of 5 minutes
items.example: “5 minutes warm up, 5 minutes finish.”

items.title: Rule 2) Sharing pain is mandatory
items.how: If you hide it, it will hurt you even more.
items.example: “If you feel any pain, tell me right away.”

items.title: Rule 3) The intensity is graded
items.how: Don't upload it all at once.
items.example: “70% today, 80% next time.”

items.title: Rule 4) Rules are announced in the meeting notice.
items.example: “4 safety rules for gatherings” fixed notice.

sections.title: Sentences that don’t make it awkward to talk about safety

items.say: “Let’s warm up together for the first 5 minutes today.”

items.situation: An atmosphere where it’s okay to talk about pain
items.say: “Telling about pain is not a nuisance, it’s a matter of safety. Let’s not overdo it.”
“This isn’t a personal story, let’s set it as a meeting rule.”

sections.title: FAQ

items.q: If you talk about safety, the atmosphere gets depressed.
items.a: All you need to do is briefly agree on the rules. The longer you persuade someone, the more resentment you will have.

title: When the gaming group’s feelings are hurt due to ‘role/position’
description: Some people want to win, some want to take it easy, and some people always take on the same role. The rule is not to turn role conflict into a human fight.

sections.title: TOP 3 role conflict patterns

items.title: 1) A specific person always plays the same role
items.when: The roles of tank/support/progress are always fixed.
items.why: It's easy to fix, but it becomes a sacrifice when accumulated.
items.tip: Rotation: **“Today A, next B”** in public.

items.title: 2) Roles are assigned like ‘orders’
items.when: It feels like a directive, not a choice.
items.why: Games have strong tastes, so coercion quickly turns into emotion.
items.tip: Suggest as a choice: **“Do you want to do A or B?”**

items.title: 3) Responsibility for mistakes falls on a specific role
items.when: Blame the loss on just one person.
items.why: Team games have a structure that makes it easy to pass on responsibility.
items.tip: Reviews are based on the team: **“Next time, let’s get the vision/timing right.”**

sections.title: When this signal appears, a role rule is needed.

items.title: When a person speaks less and less
items.detail: You may already be overburdened.

items.title: When ‘Why did you do that?’ becomes frequent
items.detail: We are moving towards criticism rather than feedback.

items.title: When only the same person takes on the sacrificial role
items.detail: Meeting continuity is reduced.

sections.title: DO/DON’T
4 rules to reduce role conflict

items.title: Rule 1) Role is rotation
items.example: “Today A, next B”

items.title: Rule 2) Assignment is optional
items.example: “Would you like to do A/B?”

items.title: Rule 3) Only 2 defeat reviews
items.how: If you overdo it, it becomes emotional.
items.example: “1 thing I liked, 1 thing I would change.”

items.title: Rule 4) ‘Practice version’ agreement
items.example: “The first two editions were adaptation editions.”

sections.title: Role related sentences

items.say: “I also want to try different roles sometimes. Let’s rotate next game.”
“Would you like to play A or B this time?”
“Let’s organize this so that we can align our movements with the team rather than blaming individuals.”

sections.title: FAQ

items.q: If you rotate, your win rate goes down.
items.a: So, you can divide the mode into ‘Practice version/Entrepreneurship version’. Both can be saved.

title: When words become harsh at a gaming meeting and ‘emotional fluctuations’ spread
description: If one person falters, the tone of the entire team is ruined. I'm not trying to eliminate anger, but I've put together the minimum rules to prevent it from spreading.

sections.title: TOP 3 patterns that spread emotional fluctuations

items.title: 1) The point comes out ‘immediately’
items.when: Immediately after making a mistake, words are spoken first.
items.why: When emotions are heightened, sentences sound like attacks.
items.tip: Prohibited during the game: **After the review, only 2 comments**

items.title: 2) The joke turns into sarcasm.
items.when: What you meant to be funny sounds like ridicule to the other person.
items.why: The sharper the text/voice tone, the worse the interpretation.
items.tip: Target fixation: **Situation, not person**

items.title: 3) Continuous cue without mood recovery
items.when: After a bad game, you immediately go in and fail even more.
items.why: Emotions accumulate with no recovery time.
items.tip: 2 minutes reset: **Glass of water + One sentence summary**

sections.title: When you see this signal, stop for a second.

items.title: Talk begins to emerge
items.detail: It's turning into an emotional battle rather than a game.

items.title: the silence gets longer
items.detail: Discomfort may have already built up.

items.title: Forced to the next round after consecutive losses
items.detail: There is a high risk of cumulative emotional fluctuations.

sections.title: DO/DON’T
4 rules to prevent emotional fluctuations from spreading

items.title: Rule 1) No pointing during the game
items.example: “Let’s clean up after this.”

items.title: Rule 2) Only 2 reviews
items.example: “1 thing I liked, 1 thing I would change.”

items.title: Rule 3) Reset 2 minutes
items.example: “Two minutes rest, next time.”

items.title: Rule 4) If the tone wavers, call
items.how: There are fewer misunderstandings than text.
items.example: “Let’s sum this up in words for just one minute.”

sections.title: Sentence that sums up the mood

items.situation: When talking right after a mistake
items.say: “For now, let’s focus on playing and make it short afterward.”
“Let’s not talk about people, just the situation.”
“Let’s take a two-minute break. I think I’m getting emotional now.”

sections.title: FAQ

items.q: I feel frustrated if I say anything at all.
items.a: Therefore, we need a structure that allows ‘ban during the game’ and ‘shortly after the game’.

title: When game meetings keep breaking up due to ‘connection time’
description: It's a meeting that says it's 'possible at any time', but in reality no one can meet it. How to resolve time agreements with structure, not emotion.

sections.title: TOP 3 patterns that mess up your schedule

items.title: 1) Collect only ‘possible time’ and do not confirm anything
items.when: Everyone talks about time, but there is no conclusion.
items.why: There is no end to the mix of collection and selection.
items.tip: **Separated into 24 hours of collection → 2 hours of confirmation**

items.title: 2) The person who is late becomes the standard
items.when: There is always someone waiting.
items.why: If there is no waiting rule, the person who waits loses.
items.tip: SLA Agreement: **“Wait 10 minutes, then start”**

items.title: 3) No fixed routines
items.when: Every time I try to make something new, it becomes a mess.
items.why: Without anchoring, priorities fall behind.
items.tip: 1 Fixed Slot: **“Fixed once a week, additional is a bonus”**

sections.title: When this signal comes up, you need a rule.

items.title: When waiting time increases
items.detail: Waiting has become the default for meetings.

items.title: When a diver comes out just before confirmation
items.detail: It’s a state where confirmation feels like confinement.

items.title: In the end, when only 2 or 3 people do it
items.detail: Structure throws people off.

sections.title: DO/DON’T

dont: Schedule a new schedule every time

sections.title: 4 rules for correct connection

items.title: Rule 1) 24 hours for collection
items.example: “Available times only until 9 o’clock tomorrow.”

items.title: Rule 2) Confirmation 2 hours
items.example: “Voting between A/B ends at 10 o’clock today.”

items.title: Rule 3) Wait 10 minutes
items.example: “Start after waiting 10 minutes.”

items.title: Rule 4) 1 fixed slot
items.example: “Fixed every Friday at 10 o’clock.”

sections.title: group chat sentences

items.say: “Please give me until 9 o’clock tomorrow. After that, I will post a confirmation vote through A/B.”
“Please wait until 10 minutes, and then let’s start with everyone who comes in.”
“I think creating a fixed slot once a week will reduce stress.”

sections.title: FAQ

items.q: If you make rules, they become rigid.
items.a: I get more tired when there are no rules. The minimum rule is actually more comfortable.

title: When game groups become subtle due to ‘reward/contribution’
description: Items, rewards, points, and contributions may seem small, but they convey emotions. How to organize your feelings of unfairness with rules before they build up.

sections.title: TOP 3 reward/contribution conflict patterns

items.title: 1) There are no standards and then fight after winning
items.when: When it's good, it goes over, but when it gets twisted, it explodes.
items.why: Without standards, the process only becomes problematic on days when results are bad.
items.tip: One line of agreement before starting: **“Compensation is based on ○○”**

items.title: 2) Judging contribution by words only
items.when: Only visible plays are recognized as contributions.
items.why: Contributions like support/information/calls can easily be underestimated.
items.tip: Declaration of contribution scope: **Call/vision/setting also contribute**

items.title: 3) Rewards are repeatedly lopsided
items.when: It's a coincidence, but it feels unfair.
items.why: When perceived unfairness accumulates, it cools relationships.
items.tip: Rotation or Priority: **“This time A, next time B”**

sections.title: When this signal comes, you need to set a rule first.

items.title: When sentences like “It’s always just you” appear
items.detail: Perceived unfairness has already built up.

items.title: When talk of compensation often comes up after it is ‘over’
items.detail: There may be an atmosphere where you can't talk during the game.

items.title: When assessing contribution like personality
items.detail: It becomes a relationship battle, not a game.

sections.title: DO/DON’T
4 rules to ensure a sense of fairness

items.title: Rule 1) 1 standard line before starting
items.example: Select one of “Rewards are random/contribution/need-based.”

items.title: Rule 2) Agree on contribution scope
items.example: “Call/setting/support also contributes.”

items.title: Rule 3) Priority Rotation
items.example: “This time A, next time B.”

items.title: Rule 4) Complaints will be reflected in the next edition
items.example: “Like this this time, adjust next time.”

sections.title: Reward/Contribution Sentence

items.say: “Let’s set the compensation standard first. How about going on a need basis today?”
“Call/setting is also a contribution. Let’s look at that part as well.”
“Okay. Let’s wrap it up for today and adjust the rules from the next round.”

sections.title: FAQ

items.q: The rules are getting too complicated.
items.a: You only need to decide on a single line standard. As things become more complex, disputes increase.

title: How to avoid breaking the mood when new/returning players come to a gaming group
description: Those who are good at it will feel frustrated, beginners will feel intimidated, and eventually the fun will diminish for both. How to resolve skill differences through ‘structure’ rather than ‘consideration’.

sections.title: TOP 3 patterns that make beginners feel awkward

items.title: 1) The explanation was long so it became a class.
items.when: I get tired just giving explanations before the game starts.
items.why: Explaining becomes listening, not participation.
items.tip: Explanation is 30 seconds, the rest is **one at a time**

items.title: 2) Stronger reaction after a mistake
items.when: If a beginner makes a mistake, the atmosphere becomes cold.
items.why: Beginners are more intimidated by facial expressions/tones than by the mistakes themselves.
items.tip: Consensus Sentence: **“The first two editions were adaptations”**

items.title: 3) The goal is fixed as ‘victory’
items.when: Even though it is practice, it is only evaluated as wins or losses.
items.why: There is no space for beginners to enjoy.
items.tip: Step your goals: **V1=Adapt, V2=Win**

sections.title: When this signal occurs, adaptive support structures are needed.

items.title: When Beginners Don't Ask Questions
items.detail: You may already be in a depressed state.

items.title: When a good person speaks harshly
items.detail: There is a risk that frustration can turn into aggression.

items.title: When beginners avoid their next appointment
items.detail: It became a burden rather than a joy.

sections.title: DO/DON’T

dont: Evaluated only on wins and losses

sections.title: 4 rules for beginners to blend in naturally

items.title: Rule 1) Adaptation for the first 2 editions
items.how: Familiarity is more important than winning or losing.
items.example: “The first two editions were adaptation editions.”

items.title: Rule 2) Explanation is 30 seconds
items.how: The rest are one at a time during play.
items.example: “Start by saying just one key thing.”

items.title: Rule 3) Mistakes are ‘normal’
items.example: “Mistakes are part of practice.”

items.title: Rule 4) Start with the easy roles
items.example: “Start with an easy role at first.”

sections.title: Adaptation Support Sentences

items.say: “Let’s play the first two games today as adaptive games. Don’t worry about winning or losing.”
“Let’s get started, and I’ll tell you what you need one by one.”
“It’s okay. You’re just getting used to it, so take it easy.”

sections.title: FAQ

items.q: Then cilantro is no fun.
items.a: Just separate the modes. If you put a short ‘serious version’ after the adaptation version, both satisfaction levels increase.
